entry.title: The One Thing
entry.content:
Brief summary

In his book Gary Keller explains how focusing on one task is the most efficient way to get things done. He details on why having multiple things to do at one will make anyone less performant and more distracted. He also demystifies the belief of multi-tasking. If we turn our daily to-do list into success list, we would be more productive over time.
He emphasize on the way we should attack big problems, step-by-step.

Keypoints

1 The one thing

  • Focus on one thing at a time.
  • Multitasking is a myth.
  • Extraordinary results are directly determined by how narrow you can make your focus.

2 The domino effect

  • The domino effect, small daily changes lead to huge long-term effects.
    • Find our lead domino and make it falls.

3 Success leaves clues

  • No one succeed alone.

4 Everything matters equally

  • Activity is unrelated to productivity.
  • To-do lists are survival lists.
  • Success lists are for achievers.
  • We should use the extreme pareto. 1/99% over 20/80%
  • Postpone everything which is not in the 1%.
  • Checking-off is not productivity.

5 Multitasking

  • Multitasking is a lie.
  • A multi-tasking mind is a monkey mind.
  • It’s wanting to do too many things in the time we have.
  • Less distraction and more focus on the task will lead to more productivity and time saving.
  • Why would you multi task if you still have important work.
  • Distration is natural
  • Multitasking takes a toll.
  • Distraction undermines results

6 A disciplined life

  • Success is actually a short race, a sprint fueled by discipline just long enough for habit to kick in and take over.
  • In fact less discipline is required, it just requires small steps of action.
  • Use the selected discipline.
  • When you do the right thing, it can liberate you from having to monitor everything.
  • Build a habit at a time.
  • Give each havit enough time.
    • each habit take 66 days to form.

7 Willpower is always on will-call

  • Don’t spread your willpower too thin. There is only a limited amount of willpower each day.
  • Monitor your fuel gauge. Full strenght willpower requires a full tank.
  • Time your task. Do what matters most first.
  • Don’t fight your willpower, work around it, with it.

8 A balanced life

To conclude

Where to buy

  • amazon.com
